paragraphs.text:
%md
# Bookstore Analytics Sandbox
### Overview
#### Online Bookstore Data
This sandbox is based on procedural generated sandbox representing data for a typical online bookstore. 
In the exapmles below we will try to answer the tipical questions every business user has at some point when his business catch some speed. 
Like "How am I doing?", "What can be improved?" etc. 

#### System Info
The data is loaded in a **MariaDB AX** an enterprise open source solution for modern data warehousing. Fast, powerful and scalable analytics solution on commodity hardware or cloud infrastructure.

The data size:
Cards: 1,122,245 rows
Emails: 1,796,966 rows
Phones: 1,698,696 rows
Addresses: 1,867,567 rows
Transactions: 15,413,748 rows
LoyaltyPoints: 1,259,978 rows
Customers: 1,403,909 rows
Covers: 20 rows
TransactionTypes: 3 rows
MaritalStatuses: 5 rows

msg.data:
Bookstore Analytics Sandbox

Overview

Online Bookstore Data

This sandbox is based on procedural generated sandbox representing data for a typical online bookstore.
In the exapmles below we will try to answer the tipical questions every business user has at some point when his business catch some speed.
Like “How am I doing?”, “What can be improved?” etc.

System Info

The data is loaded in a MariaDB AX an enterprise open source solution for modern data warehousing. Fast, powerful and scalable analytics solution on commodity hardware or cloud infrastructure.

The data size:
Cards: 1,122,245 rows
Emails: 1,796,966 rows
Phones: 1,698,696 rows
Addresses: 1,867,567 rows
Transactions: 15,413,748 rows
LoyaltyPoints: 1,259,978 rows
Customers: 1,403,909 rows
Covers: 20 rows
TransactionTypes: 3 rows
MaritalStatuses: 5 rows

paragraphs.text:
import java.util.Properties
import org.apache.spark.sql.SQLContext

//You can make user-defined function (UDF)and use it in a query
def sexName(s:String) : String = {
    if(s.toUpperCase=='M'.toString.toUpperCase)
        "Male"
    else
        "Female"
}

val jdbcHostname = "10.5.0.2"
val jdbcPort = 3306
val jdbcDatabase ="bookstore"
val jdbcUsername = "zeppelin_user"
val jdbcPassword ="zeppelin_pass"
val driverClass = "org.mariadb.jdbc.Driver"
// Create the JDBC URL without passing in the user and password parameters.
val jdbcUrl = s"jdbc:mysql://${jdbcHostname}:${jdbcPort}/${jdbcDatabase}"

// Create a Properties() object to hold the parameters.
val connectionProperties = new Properties()
connectionProperties.put("user", s"${jdbcUsername}")
connectionProperties.put("password", s"${jdbcPassword}")
connectionProperties.setProperty("Driver", driverClass)
connectionProperties.setProperty("fetchSize","10000")
val sqlcontext = new org.apache.spark.sql.SQLContext(sc)

// Regiter the function
sqlcontext.udf.register("sexName", sexName _)

jdbcUsername: String = zeppelin_user
jdbcPassword: String = zeppelin_pass
driverClass: String = org.mariadb.jdbc.Driver
jdbcUrl: String = jdbc:mysql://10.5.0.2:3306/bookstore

paragraphs.text:
%md 
### Books
In this first part we will focus mainly on our main commodity - the books. We want to know what we offer to our customers and how can be improved. 

Lets start by answering our first question.

**Q:**How many books do we sell?

msg.data:
Books

In this first part we will focus mainly on our main commodity - the books. We want to know what we offer to our customers and how can be improved.

Lets start by answering our first question.

Q:How many books do we sell?

paragraphs.title: Loading books ...
paragraphs.text:
// Load Books
val pushdown_query = "(select * from books) b"
val df_books = spark.read.jdbc(url=jdbcUrl, table=pushdown_query, properties=connectionProperties)
df_books.createOrReplaceTempView("books")
df_books.printSchema()

msg.data:
pushdown_query: String = (select * from books) b
df_books: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [book_id: decimal(20,0), cover_price: decimal(7,2) ... 4 more fields]
root
 |-- book_id: decimal(20,0) (nullable = false)
 |-- cover_price: decimal(7,2) (nullable = false)
 |-- isbn: string (nullable = false)
 |-- bookname: string (nullable = false)
 |-- category: string (nullable = false)
 |-- discount: decimal(7,2) (nullable = false)

paragraphs.text:
%sql
select count(*) `Total Books` from books

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
Total Books
5000

paragraphs.text:
%md
This was easy question 5000. 

Lets try something harder. 	

**Q:**We are trying to position our online bookstore towards Fantasy and Sci-Fi theme, but we are also trying to provide good variety of books as well.
Did we achieve those goals?

msg.data:
This was easy question 5000.

Lets try something harder.

Q:We are trying to position our online bookstore towards Fantasy and Sci-Fi theme, but we are also trying to provide good variety of books as well.
Did we achieve those goals?

paragraphs.title: Total number of books in Our Bookstore
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select category as `Category`, count(*) `Total Books` from books group by category ORDER BY `Total Books` DESC

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
Category	Total Books
Fantasy	889
Sci-fi	848
Romance	783
Children Classics	650
Drama	518
Mystery	470
Horror	394
Humor	266
Classics	159
Non-fiction	23

paragraphs.text:
%md
It looks like we are spot on targeting our audience.

msg.data: It looks like we are spot on targeting our audience.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Now something more tangable.

**Q:**Are we making good profit from our focus categories ?

msg.data:
Now something more tangable.

Q:Are we making good profit from our focus categories ?

paragraphs.title: Profitability Potential by Genre
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select  category, avg(cover_price) as `Avg. Price in USD`, count(*) as Items from books group by category order by `Avg. Price in USD`

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
category	Avg. Price in USD	Items
Humor	5.393195	266
Children Classics	9.463908	650
Romance	9.781252	783
Non-fiction	9.983043	23
Horror	11.111320	394
Drama	13.310811	518
Mystery	14.242681	470
Sci-fi	18.757123	848
Classics	22.914340	159
Fantasy	23.299910	889

paragraphs.text:
%md
I looks like **Fantasy** and **Sci-Fi** books have good potential for profit, if they sell.

msg.data: I looks like Fantasy and Sci-Fi books have good potential for profit, if they sell.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Now lets check if we provide enough variety in those categories. We are targeting **Sci-Fi** and **Fantasy** fans. Our catalog should be as complete as possible.
**Q:**Do we provide enough variety ?

msg.data:
Now lets check if we provide enough variety in those categories. We are targeting Sci-Fi and Fantasy fans. Our catalog should be as complete as possible.
Q:Do we provide enough variety ?

paragraphs.title: Variety by Genre
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select  category, avg(cover_price) as `Profitability Potential`, count(*) as Items from books group by category order by Items

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
category	Profitability Potential	Items
Non-fiction	9.983043	23
Classics	22.914340	159
Humor	5.393195	266
Horror	11.111320	394
Mystery	14.242681	470
Drama	13.310811	518
Children Classics	9.463908	650
Romance	9.781252	783
Sci-fi	18.757123	848
Fantasy	23.299910	889

paragraphs.text:
%md 
    The variety chart shows that we have covered **Sci-Fi** and **Fantasy** fans but also we have substential variety **Romance** and **Children** books.
We might want to explore the profitability potential those two categories. 
Lets get back and click *settings* above and deselect *items* the chart now presents the profitability potential of those books. 
It looks like  **Romance** and **Children** are not very profitable, but **Classics** are. 

As a result from this quick anlysis we already can make a decision for improvement in the future. Like how our customers like the new changes?; are they going to buy those books? etc.

Let try to identify who our customers are in the next section.

msg.data:
The variety chart shows that we have covered Sci-Fi and Fantasy fans but also we have substential variety Romance and Children books.
We might want to explore the profitability potential those two categories.
Lets get back and click settings above and deselect items the chart now presents the profitability potential of those books.
It looks like Romance and Children are not very profitable, but Classics are.

As a result from this quick anlysis we already can make a decision for improvement in the future. Like how our customers like the new changes?; are they going to buy those books? etc.

Let try to identify who our customers are in the next section.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Customers
In this section we will try to identify who our customers are ? what are their preferences? how likely is for them to buy somethin out of their main focus. 

Lets try to make a demographical profile of our customers. 

**Q:**Who is our customer ?

msg.data:
Customers

In this section we will try to identify who our customers are ? what are their preferences? how likely is for them to buy somethin out of their main focus.

Lets try to make a demographical profile of our customers.

Q:Who is our customer ?

paragraphs.title: Loading customers ...
paragraphs.text:
// Load Customers
val pushdown_query="(select c.*, ms.ms_type FROM customers c INNER JOIN maritalstatuses ms on ms.ms_id=c.ms_id) as q"
val df_customers = spark.read.jdbc(url=jdbcUrl, table=pushdown_query, properties=connectionProperties)
df_customers.createOrReplaceTempView("customers")
df_customers.printSchema()

paragraphs.text:
%md
Those we demographics only. But we want to know more about their bying habbits.
How much they buy?
How much they spend? 
What do they buy?

paragraphs.title: Loading orders ...
paragraphs.text:
// Load Transactions
val pushdown_query = "(SELECT count(t.order_id) orders, SUM(t.price), SUM(t.discounted_price) Amount, t.customer_id,  c.customer_nm, c.sex, c.age, ms.ms_type FROM transactions as t INNER JOIN customers c ON c.customer_id = t.customer_id INNER JOIN maritalstatuses ms ON ms.ms_id = c.ms_id GROUP BY  t.customer_id, c.customer_nm, c.sex, c.age, ms.ms_type ORDER BY orders desc) as t"
val df_orders = spark.read.jdbc(url=jdbcUrl, table=pushdown_query, properties=connectionProperties)
df_orders.createOrReplaceTempView("transactions")
df_orders.printSchema()

msg.data:
pushdown_query: String = (SELECT count(t.order_id) orders, SUM(t.price), SUM(t.discounted_price) Amount, t.customer_id,  c.customer_nm, c.sex, c.age, ms.ms_type FROM transactions as t INNER JOIN customers c ON c.customer_id = t.customer_id INNER JOIN maritalstatuses ms ON ms.ms_id = c.ms_id GROUP BY  t.customer_id, c.customer_nm, c.sex, c.age, ms.ms_type ORDER BY orders desc) as t
df_orders: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [orders: bigint, SUM(t.price): decimal(29,2) ... 6 more fields]

paragraphs.text:
%md
But lets start with the biggest question. 
**Q:**Who spends more men or women ?

msg.data:
But lets start with the biggest question.
Q:Who spends more men or women ?

paragraphs.title: Orders Distribution by Sex
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT SUM(orders) as Orders, sexname(sex) Sex FROM transactions group by sexName(sex)  ORDER by Sex

8004292	Female

paragraphs.title: Top Buyers Distribution by Sex
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT * FROM (SELECT max(orders) as Orders, customer_nm ,customer_id, sexname(sex) as Sex, age, ms_type  FROM transactions group by customer_nm, customer_id, Sex, age, ms_type order by Orders desc limit 10) x order by x.Sex

**Q:**But do the young read more than seniores ? 
Lets find out.

Q:But do the young read more than seniores ?

paragraphs.text: %md

paragraphs.title: Order Distribution by Age
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT age,sum(orders) as Orders, AVG(amount) as `Cart Amount`, sexname(sex) Sex FROM transactions group by age,sex

paragraphs.text:
%md 
Lets focus on our top customers and try to profile them in order to answer the following question:

**Q:**What are the reading preferencess of our top customers?

msg.data:
Lets focus on our top customers and try to profile them in order to answer the following question:

Q:What are the reading preferencess of our top customers?

paragraphs.title: Loading Top Users ...
paragraphs.text:
// Load Top users Transactions
val pushdown_query = "(SELECT c.customer_id,c.customer_nm,b.category, SUM(discounted_price) disc_price FROM bookstore.transactions AS t  INNER JOIN customers c ON c.customer_id = t.customer_id INNER JOIN books b ON b.book_id = t.book_id WHERE c.customer_id IN (60,274,2727,168,5,13,30,75,1743,2) GROUP BY  c.customer_id,c.customer_nm,b.category) as o"
val df_top_orders = spark.read.jdbc(url=jdbcUrl, table=pushdown_query, properties=connectionProperties)
df_top_orders.createOrReplaceTempView("top_transactions")
df_top_orders.printSchema()

msg.data:
pushdown_query: String = (SELECT c.customer_id,c.customer_nm,b.category, SUM(discounted_price) disc_price FROM bookstore.transactions AS t  INNER JOIN customers c ON c.customer_id = t.customer_id INNER JOIN books b ON b.book_id = t.book_id WHERE c.customer_id IN (60,274,2727,168,5,13,30,75,1743,2) GROUP BY  c.customer_id,c.customer_nm,b.category) as o
df_top_orders: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [customer_id: decimal(20,0), customer_nm: string ... 2 more fields]
